posts.name: I ask a whole lot of questions
posts.cooked: How would I use an Arduino to control Victor sp? I can‚Äôt find any recent solutions. I want to do it wirelessly and if possible pneumatics. This is for a homemade robot. Thank you
posts.display_username: I ask a whole lot of questions

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
That‚Äôs a bit of a loaded question.  First step would be to better understand the actual ‚Äúlanguage‚Äù (protocol) going across the wires.  VictorSP controllers can be controlled using a PWM signal, which can be generated by an Arduino, so that‚Äôs fine.  Pneumatic solenoids are just fancy electronic switches, so a digital output is all that‚Äôs needed for that.  An arduino can do this as well.

The implementation of these is left as an exercise for the reader though.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
First off, not on a competition robot - see R712. PWM to motor controllers must come from the RIO.

For a different purpose, the easy way is to create a servo in the Arduino code.  Then the angle you set on the servo corresponds to motor throttle, with 0 typically being full reverse, 90 being neutral, and 180 being full forward.

posts.name: Max Morehead
Tinnittin
posts.cooked: I did something similar when I was a student to control a Spark Motor Controller over PWM with a joystick. Probably not the ‚Äúbest‚Äù way to do it, but it did work.

posts.name: I ask a whole lot of questions
posts.cooked: Also how would I do a controller for the motors? I have seen robot open but is there a newer way?
posts.display_username: I ask a whole lot of questions

posts.name: Tinnittin
posts.cooked: The Servo library outputs PWM , so you can connect that directly to the Victor SP.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
Fletch1373:

‚Ä¶exercise‚Ä¶

I‚Äôd probably be in sports ball if I liked to exercise, thank God I was cut from the high school soccer team

Gabe4:

Like a way to control direction and speed wirelessly if possible

Think of this project as different parts that you want to connect. You need code that can control the motor control. You also need code to connect to it wirelessly. Finally, you need code that connects those two things together.

A quick YouTube search showed me this video . It might be helpful. Also, Arduino has lots of examples if you navigate to File > Examples. Some of that might be helpful. Once you hit another road block, feel free to check back in and we will continue to answer more specific questions.

And as others have indicated, speed controllers use Servo standards for control.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
I think they are looking for a specific guide to follow, which we can‚Äôt give without a specific protocol to follow and a reasoning as to what the end purpose is besides a non- FRC robot.

Environment it will operate in and range you want to be able to operate it from matter the most in that decision.

Bluetooth ensures you are relatively close from a safety standpoint and there and many examples from adafruit for Bluetooth control to various types of devices. If you use their shield for the Bluetooth with a regular Arduino this might be useful.

Would you like to add powerful and easy-to-use Bluetooth Low Energy to your robot, art or other electronics project? Heck yeah! With BLE now included in modern smart phones and tablets, its fun to add wireless connectivity. So what you really need is...

WiFi you would look for a similar type of add on board and follow it‚Äôs tutorials. Just substitute the victor SP for some standard motor controllers in other people‚Äôs examples. These are less safe as the range can be remote or much farther. If it‚Äôs an FRC robot with the radio that range is limited, if it‚Äôs paired to a building you could be driving blind right into someone or down a flight of stairs‚Ä¶ WiFi isn‚Äôt always safe to drive with.

Another option would be 2.4ghz 2 way radio control. Still has a range limit, but you can figure out safety shutoffs here as well.

Learn to use the nRF24L01 modules and the RadioHead Library to construct a wireless joystick to control a robot car! This article will show you how the nRF24L01 works and how to use it in your Arduino designs.

Spend some more time googling around and don‚Äôt get hung up on the Victor SP part. It can be substituted in most motor control Arduino examples that use PWM or servo to control motors.  Terms like ‚Äú PWM robot Arduino‚Äù, ‚Äú PWM motor WiFi Arduino‚Äù, Servo motor Arduino Bluetooth, Arduino Smart Car, etc.

The Victor SP is a niche product but it‚Äôs just a pwm motor controller with nothing else special about it when used that way. Don‚Äôt get stuck looking for an example with that specifically online because there won‚Äôt be one

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
kingc95:

Bluetooth ensures you are relatively close from a safety standpoint

If you‚Äôre depending on losing comms for safety, be sure to implement watchdog logic - that is, if the signal is lost for more than, say, a quarter second, the motors and other actuators turn off or go to a safe position.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
I meant more of it‚Äôs not safe to operate a robot you can‚Äôt physically see most times.

Depends on the size, payload, speed and a whole load of other factors. Is it in a safety cell that keeps humans out? Is it equipped with safety laser scanners or some sort of physical bumper switches, etc?

I for instance dislike any remote joystick that can be used over WiFi for anything FRC sized or larger. It‚Äôs all too easy to accidentally drive it past a point you can see it and run into something. Bluetooth by its own design kind of limits this without much additional work needed

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: My point was that if your robot‚Äôs response to losing comms is ‚Äúto keep doing the last thing I was doing‚Äù, loss of comms is a safety problem, not a safety solution.
